newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - Feb 24.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - Feb 24.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- President Fidel Ramos assured former President Corazon Aquino that he will step down when his term ends in June 1998. (THE MANILA TIMES,TODAY, THE PHILIPPINE DAILY INQUIRER)

- The main-opposition party Laban ng Demokratikong Pilipino (Fight for a Democratic Philippines) said funds and resources of the Philippine Coconut Authority and the Overseas Workers Welfare Administration are being used to bankroll the signature campaign for a people's initiative aimed at amending the Constitution to allow President Fidel Ramos to seek re-election in 1998. (MANILA CHRONICLE)

- A consortium led by Ayala Corp, which won the contract to run half of manila's waterworks system, will include Japan's Mitsubishi group of companies in the project, Ayala President Jaime Augusto Zobel de Ayala said. (TODAY)

- A consortium led by Benpres Holdings, which won the west zone concession of the Manila waterworks privatisation, has agreed to farm out a 10-percent interest in the project to the Philippine Investment and Management Consultants Inc (INQUIRER)

- Agriculture Secretary Salvador Escudero favours setting the sugar procurement price of the National Food Authority at no less than 600 pesos per 50-kilo bag to stabilise local prices more effectively. (BUSINESSWORLD)
